key_points: The remnants of Hurricane Ida caused devastating floods and tornado damage across the U.S. East Coast, leading to a death toll of at least 46 people.
At least 23 people died in New Jersey, 13 in New York City, with 11 of those deaths occurring in flooded basement apartments.
Significant flooding and damages were reported across multiple states including Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Maryland, Massachusetts, and Rhode Island.
Victims recounted horrific experiences of rapidly rising floodwaters, with some recounting efforts to save neighbors and loved ones.
Experts linked the intensity of the stormâ€™s aftermath to climate change, noting warmer air can hold more rain, and urban settings exacerbate flooding due to extensive pavement.
Despite warnings from the National Hurricane Center about potential flash flooding, officials in New York expressed surprise at the storm's ferocity.
Nearly 500 vehicles were abandoned on flooded highways in New York, and subway service was disrupted due to water entering the tunnels.
Officials including President Joe Biden, New York Governor Kathy Hochul, and Mayor Bill de Blasio have responded to the crisis, with federal first responders helping in cleanup efforts.
The storm also spawned at least 10 tornadoes across the region, causing additional damage.
This disaster follows just days after Ida made landfall in Louisiana as the fifth-strongest storm ever to hit the U.S.
spokespersons: Gov. Phil Murphy (Democratic Governor, New Jersey)
Mayor Bill de Blasio (Mayor, New York City)
Mayor J. Christian Bollwage (Mayor, Elizabeth, New Jersey)
Jeanine Zubrzycki (Resident, Mullica Hill, New Jersey)
